title: run_in_terminal does not wait for the executed command to terminate even with isBackground=false
body:
Type: Bug 1. Be in agent mode. 2. Bring the machine into a high load condition, e.g. short and long time CPU load higher than twice the number of logical CPUs. 3. Give a prompt which requires the execution of a (very slow) command needing the result of the last line (extreme case). 4. The agent reacts like the command never have given an output and like it did not terminate. - Even explaining the situation does not help/ leads to the agent ignoring the situation - It is expected that the agent waints until the command is finished - As a plus the agent shall have a time expectation, possibly considering the current load and capabilities of the machine, and ask the user for instructions how to handle the situation. - Yes, this is my (low spec) fallback machine, but this looks like a design flaw. title: Ad-hoc flags to exclude auto-attached context, instructions or tools
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Sometimes I would like to ask GitHub Copilot Chat simple questions that doesn't need any of the code context or copilot-instructions or tools especially when I know the model can definitely give a good answer that I just forgot the details of. Currently there is no convenient way for me to turn any of these off temporarily on demand and they effectively waste tokens and potentially erode the quality of the answer by presenting a large amount of irrelevant context.

It would be great if there are several ad-hoc flags that I can pass to tell VS Code to exclude certain context, just like how I can use flags to manually add context to the next chat turn. For example, `#noRef` to exclude code reference, `#noInstructions` to exclude any auto-attached instructions, `#noTools` to exclude tools. I expect these flags to be advanced features for users who are familiar with the capability of the models to enhance their experience.

title: Claude Code auto-compact loop

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

body: Testing #264419 Since our context window is smaller than the one that CC assumes, we adjust our returned token usage so that it triggers auto-compact on its own at the right time. But it may cut the history down to a size that still just triggers auto-compact again on the next request. Not sure why it allowed reading the whole package.json file or why it gets stuck in the prompt after compact, could even be a CC bug, but it leads to looping in vscode. [8f864981.copilotmd](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/22100866/8f864981.copilotmd) [d5a9a937.copilotmd](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/22100867/d5a9a937.copilotmd)

title: Add HELLO.md file with comprehensive tips for software engineering interns
body:
This PR introduces a new `HELLO.md` file that serves as a comprehensive onboarding guide specifically designed for software engineering interns contributing to the VS Code repository.

## What's included

The document provides practical guidance across multiple areas:

**Technical Foundation:**
- VS Code architecture overview with key directories and layered design principles
- TypeScript coding guidelines with examples specific to the VS Code codebase
- Development workflow best practices including branching, testing, and code review processes

**Development Skills:**
- Debugging techniques using VS Code's own tools and Chrome DevTools
- Testing strategies with specific commands for unit and integration tests
- Performance considerations for a large-scale application like VS Code

**Professional Development:**
- Communication best practices for open source collaboration
- GitHub workflow guidance including issue reporting and pull request management
- Learning resources and skill development paths for career growth

**Practical Wisdom:**
- Common pitfalls categorized into technical, process, and collaboration mistakes
- Specific examples of what to avoid and how to prevent issues
- Links to essential documentation and community resources

## Why this matters

Currently, the repository has excellent technical documentation but lacks guidance specifically tailored for interns who may be new to:
- Large-scale open source projects
- Complex TypeScript/Electron applications
- Professional software development workflows

This guide bridges that gap by providing actionable advice that helps interns become productive contributors more quickly while avoiding common mistakes.

## Document structure

The 235-line document (1,333 words) is organized with:
- Clear table of contents for easy navigation
- Practical code examples demonstrating proper patterns
- Links to existing documentation to avoid duplication
- Professional tone consistent with the repository's documentation style

The content complements existing documentation like `CONTRIBUTING.md` and `README.md` rather than replacing it, providing intern-specific guidance while referencing the authoritative sources for detailed technical information.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT SUFFIX -->

Created from VS Code via the [GitHub Pull Request](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=GitHub.vscode-pull-request-github) extension.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT TIPS -->
---

💡 You can make Copilot smarter by setting up custom instructions, customizing its development environment and configuring Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers. Learn more [Copilot coding agent tips](https://gh.io/copilot-coding-agent-tips) in the docs.

title: edit to add github.copilot to devcontainer.json does not change setting

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

body:
Testing #263837

1. create devcontainer.json (without copilot chat ext)
2. disable ai with `chat.disableAIFeatures true`
3. (now it works well with the AI disabled and the vscode copilot extension is not enabled)
4. edit the devcontainer.json to include the `"github.copilot"` extension
5. the window will prompt you to rebuild dev container as devcontainer.json changed
6. select rebuild
7. 🐛 the `chat.disableAIFeatures true` is still set. This feels like it goes against how this edge case should work - "set chat.disableAIFeatures to true but install Copilot manually via extensions view, verify the AI UI appears and chat.disableAIFeatures flips to false" but maybe it is a different scenario since it is not via the ext view but instead the devcontainer.json file.

this might be the expected behavior but wanted to bring it up in case it is not (or in case it is something you can add)

title: Fix tooltip display for two-row chat session items
body:
Chat session items can be rendered in two different layouts:
1. **Single-row**: Shows only the session title
2. **Two-row**: Shows session title on the first row and description on the second row

The issue was that tooltips were only set on the resource label (first row) via `setResource()`. When users hovered over the description row in two-row layouts, they couldn't see the tooltip.

## Changes Made

- **Added `IHoverService` dependency** to `SessionsRenderer` constructor
- **Modified tooltip logic** in `renderElement()`:
  - For single-row items: Keep existing behavior (tooltip on resource label)  
  - For two-row items: Set tooltip on the container element using `hoverService.setupDelayedHover()`
- **Proper cleanup**: Tooltip disposables are added to `templateData.elementDisposable`

## Behavior After Fix

**Single-row rendering** (when `ShowAgentSessionsViewDescription` is false or no description):
- Tooltip appears when hovering over the session title
- Maintains existing behavior

**Two-row rendering** (when `ShowAgentSessionsViewDescription` is true and session has description):
- Tooltip appears when hovering anywhere on the session item (both title and description rows)
- Fixes the reported issue

The implementation handles both string and markdown tooltip content correctly and ensures proper disposal of hover service resources.

title: Keep multiple cursors on paste
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

When I do a copy with multiple cursors, and paste it into a place with just one, it puts them all at that cursor on separate lines, but only leaves one cursor afterwards.  When I'm doing this, 99% of the time my next action is to put a cursor on every line again so I can continue working with the lines 'in bulk' ; and it also feels more natural that if I copy many cursors, then it should paste with many cursors too.  

Expected that this would already be a setting, but couldn't really find much in vs code or online (although it's a really annoying phrase to search for well...)

title: Search results include ignored files after specifying include pattern
body:
Type: Bug 1. Open a new folder to create an empty workspace. 2. Create a `.txt` file with some dummy content (e.g., just the letter `a`) and save it. 3. Close the `.txt` file in the editor (close the tab). 4. Create a `.gitignore` file to exclude the `.txt` file you just created. 5. Go to the **Search** tab in VSCode and search for `a`. You should notice that no results are returned because the **Use Exclude Settings and Ignore Files** option is enabled (this is expected result). 6. In the _files to include_ field, write a pattern that matches the file you created in step 2, like `*.txt`. This time, the search will return the file, which is not expected since it should have been excluded. title: Copilot Chat is stuck in a loop, providing the same answer to different questions and causing instability.
body:
Type: Bug Certamente. Ecco una bozza per la segnalazione del bug, scritta in inglese come richiesto dal modulo di VS Code. Puoi fare copia e incolla dei testi nei campi corrispondenti. Titolo: Copilot Chat is stuck in a loop, providing the same answer to different questions and causing instability. Passaggi da riprodurre: Description of the problem: For the entire day, the GitHub Copilot Chat extension has been unstable and is currently unusable. The core issue is that it gets stuck on a single response and repeatedly provides that same answer to any new, completely different questions asked. Steps to Reproduce: Open a new chat session with GitHub Copilot Chat. Ask an initial question (e.g., "How do I create a class in JavaScript?"). Copilot provides an answer (Answer A). In the same chat, ask a completely different question (e.g., "si puoi aiutarmi, ma perchè se ti faccio una domanda sul codice mi rispondi sempre uguale?"). Expected Result: Copilot should provide a new, relevant answer (Answer B) to the second question. Actual Result: Copilot ignores the new question and provides the exact same initial response (Answer A). This behavior persists for all subsequent questions, making any conversation impossible. Additional Issues: The extension has been generally unstable. At one point today, it caused the entire Visual Studio Code editor to crash. Due to this repetitive behavior and instability, the extension is currently unusable. title: LM API - documentation feedback
body:
Testing #264436

The `LanguageModelChatInformation` declaration is missing the `requiresAuthorization` field which is later present in the sample to implement `prepareLanguageModelChatInformation()`.

```ts
interface LanguageModelChatInformation {
    readonly id: string;                    // Unique identifier for the model - unique within the provider
    readonly name: string;                  // Human-readable name of the language model - shown in the model picker
    readonly family: string;                // Model family name
    readonly version: string;               // Version string
    readonly maxInputTokens: number;        // Maximum number of tokens the model can accept as input
    readonly maxOutputTokens: number;       // Maximum number of tokens the model is capable of producing
    readonly tooltip?: string;              // Optional tooltip text when hovering the model in the UI
    readonly detail?: string;               // Human-readable text that is rendered alongside the model
    readonly capabilities: {
        readonly imageInput?: boolean;      // Supports image inputs
        readonly toolCalling?: boolean | number; // Supports tool calling
    };
}
```

title: Add comprehensive emoji UI guidelines documentation
body:
This PR adds a comprehensive documentation guide for using emojis in VS Code UI elements, addressing the need for consistent and accessible emoji usage across the codebase.

## What's Added

The new document at `.github/instructions/emoji-ui-guidelines.md` provides:

- **Clear usage guidelines** defining when emojis are appropriate (status indicators, git commits, file types) and when to avoid them (error messages, API names, critical notifications)
- **Technical implementation guidance** referencing existing VS Code utilities like `src/vs/base/common/strings.ts` for emoji detection and `extensions/git/src/emoji.ts` for git emoji support
- **Accessibility best practices** covering screen reader compatibility, alternative text requirements, and WCAG compliance
- **Cross-platform considerations** addressing Unicode compatibility, performance, and consistent rendering across Windows, macOS, and Linux
- **Code examples** showing proper implementation patterns and common pitfalls to avoid

## Technical Details

The document leverages VS Code's existing emoji infrastructure:

```typescript
// References existing utilities for emoji detection
export function isEmojiImprecise(x: number): boolean {
    return (x >= 0x1F1E6 && x <= 0x1F1FF) || /* ... */;
}

// Shows proper usage of git extension emoji support
return message.replace(emojiRegex, (s, code) => {
    return emojiMap?.[code] || s;
});
```

## Key Guidelines Established

- **Accessibility first**: Always provide text alternatives, never use emoji-only interactive elements
- **Professional tone**: Use emojis sparingly to maintain VS Code's professional appearance
- **Technical considerations**: Handle complex emoji sequences (ZWJ, modifiers, skin tones) properly
- **Testing requirements**: Include emoji test cases for proper deletion, copy/paste, and search behavior

This documentation follows the established pattern in `.github/instructions/` and serves as a reference for contributors working on UI features that may incorporate emojis.

title: Add strategic emojis to README for improved visual hierarchy
body:
Enhanced the VS Code README with strategic emoji additions to improve visual hierarchy and user experience without overwhelming the content. The changes focus on making the document more scannable and engaging while maintaining the professional appearance appropriate for a Microsoft open source project.

## Changes Made

**Section Headers:** Added relevant emojis to all major sections to create better visual hierarchy:
- 🏗️ The Repository
- 💻 Visual Studio Code  
- 🤝 Contributing
- 💬 Feedback
- 🔗 Related Projects
- 📦 Bundled Extensions
- 🐳 Development Container
- 📋 Code of Conduct
- 📄 License

**Action Items:** Enhanced key actions with intuitive emojis to help users quickly identify what they're looking for:
- ⬇️ Download links
- 🐛 Bug submissions and issue filing
- 👀 Code review activities
- 📖 Documentation review
- 🔨 Building from source
- 🐞 Development workflow and debugging
- 📝 Coding guidelines
- 🔄 Pull request process
- 🔍 Finding issues to work on
- 🌐 Translation contributions

**Community Links:** Added emojis to feedback and community interaction points:
- ❓ Stack Overflow questions
- ✨ Feature requests
- 👍 Upvoting popular requests
- 💭 GitHub Discussions and Slack
- 🐦 Twitter engagement

## Implementation Notes

- Made minimal changes (25 insertions, 25 deletions) preserving all existing content
- Selected emojis that are universally recognizable and professional
- Avoided overuse by focusing only on section headers and key action items
- Maintained accessibility by keeping all text content intact
- Follows common GitHub README practices seen in major open source projects

The result is a more visually appealing and navigable README that helps users quickly find the information they need while preserving the document's authoritative and professional tone.

title: Should the run_terminal tool also allow free input in addition to multiple-choice options?

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

body:
Testing #263329

- I ran the request `Can you please run test.zsh using sudo`
- The model tries to run `sudo zsh test.zsh`
- As expected the terminal asks me to input the password
- Can the model chat also display in this case an inline panel chat widget with an input where you could type the password which would be forwarded to the terminal? Not sure if there is a security risk associated with this idea.
